metadata.title: Kong Yiji
metadata.description: The only long-gowned customer who drank his wine standing

hero.title: Kong Yiji
hero.subtitle: The only long-gowned customer who drank his wine standing
hero.author: Lu Xun

content.intro: The Xianheng Tavern in Luzhen was a place where one could witness all the warmth and coldness of human nature.

part1.p1: The layout of taverns in Luzhen was different from elsewhere. Facing the street was a large L-shaped counter with hot water kept ready to warm wine at any time. Workers who had finished their shifts would spend four copper coins for a bowl of wine and drink standing by the counter; only by spending over a dozen coins could one buy a meat dish.
part1.p2: Short-coated workers drank standing, long-gowned scholars drank seated. This was the unwritten rule in Luzhen's taverns.
part1.p3: I started working at the Xianheng Tavern when I was twelve. The shopkeeper had a fierce face, and the customers were never pleasant, leaving no room for liveliness. Only when Kong Yiji came could one have a few laughs.

part2.p1: Kong Yiji was the only long-gowned customer who drank his wine standing. He was tall, with a pale face often marked with scars between the wrinkles, and an unkempt graying beard. Though he wore a long gown, it was filthy and tattered.
part2.p2: When he spoke, he was always full of classical phrases that were half-understood. Because his surname was Kong, people took his nickname from the practice copybook phrase "Shang Da Ren Kong Yi Ji."

part3.p1: Whenever Kong Yiji arrived, everyone drinking would watch him and laugh. Someone would deliberately shout: "You must have stolen something again!"
part3.p2: Kong Yiji's face would flush red, the veins on his forehead bulging, as he argued: "Taking books cannot be considered stealing... Taking books! Can a scholar's affairs be called stealing?" Then came incomprehensible phrases that made everyone roar with laughter. Inside and outside the tavern was filled with a cheerful atmosphere.

part4.p1: Kong Yiji knew he couldn't chat with them, so he would only talk to children. Once he asked me: "Have you studied? How do you write the 'hui' in fennel beans?"

content.transition: Kong Yiji brought such merriment, but without him, life went on just the same.

part5.p1: One day, the shopkeeper was slowly settling accounts when he suddenly said: "Kong Yiji hasn't come for a long time. He still owes nineteen coins!" A drinker said: "How could he come? His legs were broken."
part5.p2: After the Mid-Autumn Festival, the autumn wind grew colder day by day. One afternoon, suddenly came a voice: "Warm a bowl of wine." Though the voice was very low, it sounded familiar. Standing up to look outside, there was Kong Yiji sitting below the counter against the threshold.

ending.p1: After that, Kong Yiji was not seen again for a long time. At year's end, the shopkeeper took down the chalk board and said: "Kong Yiji still owes nineteen coins!" At the Dragon Boat Festival the next year, he said it again. By Mid-Autumn he said nothing, and by year's end he was still not seen.
ending.final: To this day I have never seen him again â€” Kong Yiji must indeed be dead.

scene1.label: First Appearance
scene1.dialogue: Warm two bowls of wine, and a dish of fennel beans.
scene1.caption: He laid out nine large coins

scene2.label: Teaching the Character
scene2.dialogue: There are four ways to write 'hui', do you know?
scene2.caption: He dipped his nail in wine, wanting to write on the counter

scene3.label: Sharing Fennel Beans
scene3.dialogue1: Not many left, I don't have many left.
scene3.caption: And so the children dispersed amid laughter

scene4.label: The Last Time
scene4.caption: He slowly walked away using his hands
